thread.title: Snake catcher grabs a KING COBRA with his bare hands | Daily Mail Online
thread.title_full: Snake catcher grabs a KING COBRA with his bare hands | Daily Mail Online

author: Harriet Mallinson For Mailonline
title: Snake catcher grabs a KING COBRA with his bare hands | Daily Mail Online
text: Share this article Share The snake catcher asks his companion: 'Go to the head end' (the most dangerous part) and comforting him by telling him: 'Don't worry, these snakes are not as fast as smaller species'. The king cobra is the world's longest venomous snake, and can grow to 5.5m in length. In the clip, taken by Atiwit Labyosthannasi, the snake's loud 'growling' hiss can be heard which is part of its attack mechanism Eventually he manages to pick it up entirely and place it into a large white bag In a single bite king cobras can deliver seven milliliters of neurotoxin - enough to kill 20 people, or even an elephant When confronted, they can raise up to one-third of their bodies straight off the ground and still move forward to attack while flaring out their iconic hoods. In a single bite they can deliver seven milliliters of neurotoxin - enough to kill 20 people, or even an elephant. Found predominantly in and around forests India, southern China, and Southeast Asia, king cobras are fortunately shy and will avoid humans whenever possible, but are fiercely aggressive when cornered.
